Title: Speaking to Funders Without Shrinking the System
Overall Purpose: To communicate the vision, value, and integrity of the system to funders in a way that maintains its full scope, complexity, and long-term intent.
Why This Matters: In efforts to appeal to funders, there is a risk of oversimplifying or altering the system’s essence. Protecting its wholeness in communication ensures that funding supports the actual vision rather than a diluted version.
When To Use This Protocol:
When preparing funding pitches or proposals
When refining messaging for philanthropic or investment audiences
When training team members to represent the system to funders
When re-engaging existing funders with updates

Overall Outcomes.Poor: Messaging is oversimplified or altered to match perceived funder preferences → The future sees mission drift and reduced integrity.
Overall Outcomes.Expected: Some elements of wholeness are preserved, but complexity is softened for accessibility → The future risks gradual narrowing of vision.
Overall Outcomes.Excellent: The system is communicated in its full truth and value while remaining accessible → The future receives aligned funding without distortion.
Overall Outcomes.Transcendent: Speaking in wholeness is cultural instinct—funders engage with and protect the system’s integrity → The future compounds resources and trust.

Themes.Name: Holding the Full Picture
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure that all communications reflect the complete scope and intent of the system.
Themes.Why This Matters: Leaving out essential elements for the sake of simplicity risks misrepresentation and misaligned funding.

Poor.Present pattern: Essential complexity is removed to please funders.
Poor.Edge condition: You fear complexity will alienate funders.

Expected.Present pattern: Most of the system is presented, but some depth lost.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You refuse to omit integral parts.
Transcendent.Example moves: Embedded wholeness brief in all pitches.

Guiding Questions: Are we showing the whole system?
What would be lost if we removed this element?
How can we make complexity clear without oversimplifying?

Themes.Name: Framing Complexity as a Strength
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To position the system’s complexity as a core advantage rather than a liability.
Themes.Why This Matters: Funders often seek simple stories, but real transformation requires layered, interconnected systems.

Poor.30-90 day system effect: Funding favors simpler but less effective approaches.
Poor.Edge condition: You assume funders can’t handle complexity.
Poor.Example moves: Only showing one program in funding deck.

Expected.Present pattern: Some complexity is acknowledged, but framed defensively.

Excellent.Present pattern: Complexity is embraced and explained as a strength.
Excellent.Signals: Funder repeats complexity as a selling point.
Excellent.Edge condition: You use stories to make complexity relatable.

Transcendent.Edge condition: You never reduce complexity for approval.

Guiding Questions: How is our complexity part of our value?
What examples show complexity producing results?
How can we make this complexity relatable?

Themes.Name: Setting Funder Expectations Early
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To ensure funders understand the system’s pace, metrics, and rhythms before committing.
Themes.Why This Matters: Misaligned expectations cause pressure to shrink or change the system post-funding.

Poor.Present pattern: Expectations left vague until after commitment.
Poor.Immediate cost: Pressure to conform to funder timelines.
Poor.Edge condition: You fear losing funding by being upfront.

Expected.Present pattern: Some expectations set, but not comprehensive.

Excellent.Present pattern: Clear expectations set on pace, scope, and outcomes.

Transcendent.30-90 day system effect: No pressure to shrink or distort.
Transcendent.Signals: Funder reinforces realistic pace with others.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You decline funders who resist aligned pacing.
Transcendent.Example moves: Culture of truth-first in funding talks.

Guiding Questions: Have we set realistic expectations for pace and scope?
Do funders understand our metrics and rhythms?
What would change if they didn’t?

Themes.Name: Using Stories That Preserve Integrity
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To choose narratives that connect with funders emotionally while maintaining the system’s truth.
Themes.Why This Matters: Stories can inspire without distorting reality; the wrong story can oversimplify and weaken understanding.

Poor.Present pattern: Stories chosen purely for appeal, not accuracy.
Poor.Example moves: Cherry-picking examples to fit funder bias.

Expected.Present pattern: Some accuracy in stories, but details sacrificed for effect.

Guiding Questions: Are our stories both inspiring and true?
Do they preserve the system’s complexity?
How do we validate the stories we tell?

Themes.Name: Maintaining Confidence in Wholeness
Themes.Purpose of This Theme: To communicate from a place of grounded confidence in the system’s value and design.
Themes.Why This Matters: If you doubt the system’s wholeness, it’s easier to let funder preferences reshape it.

Excellent.Edge condition: You speak with conviction and clarity.

Transcendent.Present pattern: Confidence in wholeness is cultural instinct.
Transcendent.Signals: Funders adopt system language as their own.
Transcendent.Edge condition: You never diminish wholeness for appeal.
Transcendent.Example moves: Culture of confidence in all external talks.

Guiding Questions: Do we believe in the system’s wholeness?
How does that show in our language?
Where are we tempted to compromise for approval?

Completion Prompts: Capture one key element you will communicate fully to funders.
Identify one story that preserves the system's integrity.
Choose one way to frame complexity as a strength in your next pitch.
